titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Anne Ackerman Finnie Papers
titlestmt.author: Daniel Hartwig

publicationstmt.publisher: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit

did.head: Overview
did.abstract: Typescript copy of "Pamela goes to college," a parody on PAMELA by Richardson (1740), written by undergraduate Anne Ackerman, for Professor Everett Smith's English class while Miss Ackerman lived in the Stanford Union. Typescript copy of "European thought and culture," by Anne Ackerman, a description of Professor Edward Hulme and his class. Blue book from a French exam, ca. 1933. Published story, "Soda Seekers at the Sorbonne," PACIFIC WEEKLY, March 1935.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

accessrestrict.head: Information about Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: Anne Ackerman Finnie Papers (SCM0235). Department of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Sketch
bioghist.p: Anne Ackerman was a member of the Stanford University class of 1934, receiving her A.B. in French in 1935.

scopecontent.head: Description of the Collection
scopecontent.p: Typescript copy of "Pamela goes to college," a parody on PAMELA by Richardson (1740), written by undergraduate Anne Ackerman, for Professor Everett Smith's English class while Miss Ackerman lived in the Stanford Union. Typescript copy of "European thought and culture," by Anne Ackerman, a description of Professor Edward Hulme and his class. Blue book from a French exam, ca. 1933. Published story, "Soda Seekers at the Sorbonne," PACIFIC WEEKLY, March 1935.
